Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a high-performance computing cluster to enhance undergraduate research and education across the sciences at Oberlin College
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract:
An award is made to Oberlin College to support acquisition of a high-performance computational (HPC) cluster. As part of its educational mission, Oberlin College emphasizes undergraduate research and hence endeavors to provide the facilities and institutional support to sustain meaningful, student-centered faculty research. Numerous science faculty have externally funded research programs, an increasing number of which depend on high-performance computing. The cluster will be used by more than a dozen Oberlin faculty in departments throughout the natural and social sciences to support a diverse array of research, ranging from modeling black hole collisions to analyzing the effects of organic molecules on air quality, and from determining the protein characteristics of the earliest life on Earth to reconstructing the evolution of flowering plants using massive amounts of DNA sequence data. The award will also have a dramatic impact on student research and training. More than 100 Oberlin undergraduates per year will perform analyses on the computing cluster through mentored research and class-associated projects in at least eight courses, in the Departments of Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Physics, and Psychology.

Technical Abstract:
The award will fund the acquisition of a greatly improved high-performance computational (HPC) cluster that will fill a pressing need for computational support of research, research training, and teaching at Oberlin College. To facilitate the diverse computational needs of Oberlin science faculty, a cluster that maximizes parallelization while also offering multiple nodes with relatively large amounts of RAM for protein folding analyses, de novo assembly of next-generation sequencing data, and large-scale phylogenetic analyses will be installed. The cluster will include at least 38 Intel Xeon E5 compute nodes with a total of 544 cores, with RAM varying across these nodes from 32 GB/node to 512 GB/node. The cluster will also include at least two Nvidia Tesla K20 GPUs and at least two Intel Xeon Phi 5110P coprocessors to dramatically increase processing speeds for jobs that are embarrassingly parallel, and will have at least 244 TB of long-term storage space. The HPC cluster will thus have sufficient computational power and long-term archival storage to advance the increasingly large genomics, chemistry, and physics data sets that several Oberlin faculty now use in their research, and will have the flexibility to be utilized by the increasing number of Oberlin faculty who incorporate HPC work in their research, including in astrophysics, genomics, phylogenetics, proteomics, metabolomics, biophysics, atmospheric chemistry, behavioral psychology, cognitive neuroscience, and computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Oberlin has long been a leader in preparing undergraduates for future careers in science, consistently graduating more students who go on to earn Ph.D.s than any other private, primarily undergraduate institution. As part of its educational mission, Oberlin emphasizes undergraduate research and hence endeavors to provide the facilities and institutional support to sustain meaningful faculty research. Numerous science faculty have externally funded research programs, an increasing number of which depend on high-performance computing. 

 

This award provided funding to install a new, greatly expanded supercomputer to meet Oberlin’s pressing current and future computational research needs. The final supercomputer specifications include 976 computer cores distributed across 44 processor nodes, each with 256-768 GB of RAM, as well as two GPU nodes, a Xeon Phi node, and 192 TB of storage space. The supercomputer has been named SCIURus; the name was selected in part as an acronym for "SuperComputing In Undergraduate Research" and in part because the Latin name of the genus of squirrels (the unofficial mascot of Oberlin) is Sciurus. SCIURus is housed in a dedicated computational facility on the campus of Oberlin College that is designed to accommodate future expansions of the supercomputer.

 

SCIURus has supported research throughout the natural and social sciences at Oberlin, including research in astrophysics, genomics, phylogenetics, proteomics, metabolomics, biophysics, atmospheric chemistry, behavioral psychology, cognitive neuroscience, computer science, economics, and historical textual analysis. Several of the faculty that currently use the supercomputer in their research were hired during the life of the award, and it is anticipated that SCIURus will continue to attract new faculty users in the future, further diversifying the research and teaching utility of the instrument.

 

This award has also led to dramatic broader impacts in undergraduate education and training, and will continue to do so long after the end of the award period. Since the supercomputer was installed in 2015, a total of 31 Oberlin College undergraduate students have been granted their own research accounts, giving them the ability to execute their own computational analyses on SCIURus as part of mentored research projects under the supervision of Oberlin faculty advisors. In addition, over 500 Oberlin undergraduate students per year (representing nearly one quarter of all students in the College of Arts and Sciences) execute analyses as part of class-associated projects in ten courses, in the Departments of Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science, Physics, and Psychology. Faculty and students have presented the results of their research at various venues, ranging from international research conferences to undergraduate research poster sessions at Oberlin College.
